title: Association of VTEC O157 and O26 strains with the bovine intestinal mucosa ex vivo.
abstractText: Please see case uploaded by Prof. Frankel (F442400).
findingsText: By developing bovine in vitro organ culture models of infection, we were able to study the attachment and subsequent cellular subversion processes caused by enterohaemorrhagic Escherichia coli O157:H7 and related serotypes. Such a novel procedure reduced the number of animals required to undertake such studies. Many bacterial strains can be studied using a single animal, thereby significantly promoting the 3Rs. Adopting the technique, that is, dissecting and culturing intestinal organs for optimum viability and use to study host-pathogen interactions without use of whole animals, advancing the 3Rs theme.
